pButton.Name: Don’t
pButton.popInfo: Do not use contractions in academic writing. Spell out every word.

pButton.Name: Don’t
pButton.popInfo: Do not use familiar address, such as “you,” “we,” “I,” “me,” “us,” and “our.”

pButton.Name: Don’t
pButton.popInfo: Do not be sloppy by using the word “their” when you mean “there,” or using “then” when you mean “than.”

pButton.Name: DO
pButton.popInfo: Use the third-person “he” or “she,” or even “one.” For example, “Writing may be difficult if one has not mastered words effectively.”

pButton.Name: DO
pButton.popInfo: If you are writing about specific people, use their whole name or just their last name. For example, “Miller wrote the play after being questioned by the House Un-American Activities Committee.”

pButton.Name: Don’t
pButton.popInfo: Do not use slang or colloquialisms. For example, write "children" rather than "kids," and use "police officer" rather than "cop."

pButton.Name: Don’t
pButton.popInfo: Do not use words such as “never” and “always” unless you have a citation for confirmation.
